articles.headline: Workers Say Railroads’ Efficiency Push Became Too Much
articles.snippet: Employees say the inflexibility of scheduling upended their personal lives. The companies say they maintained service while using fewer resources.
articles.abstract: Employees say the inflexibility of scheduling upended their personal lives. The companies say they maintained service while using fewer resources.
articles.lead_paragraph: To defuse a labor dispute that brought the nation to the brink of a potentially catastrophic railroad strike, negotiators had to resolve a key issue: schedules that workers say were punishing, upending their personal lives and driving colleagues from the industry.
articles.byline: By Noam Scheiber and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: With Faraway Migrant Drop-Offs, G.O.P. Governors Are Doubling Down
articles.snippet: Decisions to bus migrants to the vice president’s residence and to fly others to Martha’s Vineyard were the latest attempts to provoke outrage over record arrivals at the border.
articles.abstract: Decisions to bus migrants to the vice president’s residence and to fly others to Martha’s Vineyard were the latest attempts to provoke outrage over record arrivals at the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: EDGARTOWN, Mass. — Immigration lawyers rushed onto ferries to reach a quaint red church turned shelter. Students from a high school Spanish class sought to help translate. Impromptu volunteers scoured a dollar store for clothing to donate.
articles.byline: By Will Sennott, Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Eileen Sullivan and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: Putin Nods to Xi’s ‘Concerns,’ and the Limits of Their Cooperation
articles.snippet: The discordant messages of China’s president, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia suggested that despite an earlier pledge of “friendship,” Moscow does not have an unconditional ally in Beijing.
articles.abstract: The discordant messages of China’s president, Xi Jinping, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia suggested that despite an earlier pledge of “friendship,” Moscow does not have an unconditional ally in Beijing.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Vladimir V. Putin acknowledged on Thursday that China had “questions and concerns” about Russia’s war in Ukraine, a notable, if cryptic, admission that Moscow lacks the full backing of its biggest, most powerful partner on the world stage.
articles.byline: By Anton Troianovski and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Judge Keeps Block on Inquiry Into Mar-a-Lago Files and Names Special Master
articles.snippet: The Justice Department is planning to appeal, but the decision is likely to significantly delay its investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of government records.
articles.abstract: The Justice Department is planning to appeal, but the decision is likely to significantly delay its investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of government records.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A federal judge on Thursday rejected the Justice Department’s request to resume a key part of its inquiry into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of sensitive government records and appointed an outside arbiter to review thousands of documents seized last month from his Florida residence.
articles.byline: By Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Britain’s Spending and Tax Cut Plans Worry Investors in Its Debt
articles.snippet: Simultaneous declines in bonds, stocks and the pound could set the stage for rising borrowing costs and persistent inflation.
articles.abstract: Simultaneous declines in bonds, stocks and the pound could set the stage for rising borrowing costs and persistent inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Much of the outward business of government in Britain is grinding to a halt during 10 days of national mourning until the state funeral for Queen Elizabeth II, when schools, doctors offices and many shops will close.

articles.headline: Democrats Buoyed by Abortion and Trump, Times/Siena Poll Finds
articles.snippet: President Biden’s approval rating has climbed to 42 percent, and the number of Americans who believe the country is on the right track has doubled but remains low.
articles.abstract: President Biden’s approval rating has climbed to 42 percent, and the number of Americans who believe the country is on the right track has doubled but remains low.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as they struggle to persuade voters that they should be trusted on the economy, Democrats remain unexpectedly competitive in the battle for Congress as the sprint to November’s midterm election begins, a New York Times/Siena College poll has found.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer and Nate Cohn

articles.headline: TikTok’s C.E.O. Navigates the Limits of His Power
articles.snippet: Shou Zi Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, is balancing how to be an autonomous leader while juggling the demands of the app’s Chinese parent company.
articles.abstract: Shou Zi Chew, TikTok’s chief executive, is balancing how to be an autonomous leader while juggling the demands of the app’s Chinese parent company.
articles.lead_paragraph: TikTok recently tried to tamp down concerns from U.S. lawmakers that it poses a national security threat because it is owned by the Chinese internet company ByteDance. The viral video app insisted it had an arm’s-length relationship with ByteDance and that its own executive was in charge.
articles.byline: By Ryan Mac and Chang Che

articles.headline: At Millions Per Detainee, Guantánamo Prison Stuck in a Cycle of Costly Delays
articles.snippet: The mission has relied on short-term fixes for things like housing and medical care for two decades. With 36 detainees left, the prison will soon receive its 21st commander.
articles.abstract: The mission has relied on short-term fixes for things like housing and medical care for two decades. With 36 detainees left, the prison will soon receive its 21st commander.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — Fungus was growing in a new $10 million tiny-house village being assembled at Camp Justice, the military court compound at Guantánamo Bay that has been troubled by mold for years. So plans to house lawyers assigned to the Sept. 11 case there have been postponed until late next year.

articles.headline: For Gen Z, TikTok Is the New Search Engine
articles.snippet: Need to find a restaurant or figure out how to do something? Young people are turning to TikTok to search for answers. Google has noticed.
articles.abstract: Need to find a restaurant or figure out how to do something? Young people are turning to TikTok to search for answers. Google has noticed.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Ja’Kobi Moore decided to apply this year to a private high school in her hometown of New Orleans, she learned that she needed at least one letter of recommendation from a teacher. She had never asked for one, so she sought help.

articles.headline: Stocks Slide in One of Wall Street’s Worst Weeks This Year
articles.snippet: Pessimism is deepening as bellwether companies like FedEx and General Electric warn of worsening economic and business conditions.
articles.abstract: Pessimism is deepening as bellwether companies like FedEx and General Electric warn of worsening economic and business conditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stocks fell on Friday, ending one of the worst weeks of the year for Wall Street. But a parade of prominent investors and corporate executives made it clear that they believed the worst was yet to come for the economy and financial markets.

articles.headline: At eBay, Lurid Crimes and the Search for Punishment
articles.snippet: The victims of a bizarre cyberstalking operation are trying to hold the chief executive and the culture of the company responsible.
articles.abstract: The victims of a bizarre cyberstalking operation are trying to hold the chief executive and the culture of the company responsible.
articles.lead_paragraph: “If you are ever going to take her down .. now is the time.”
